¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing for roughness of the voice and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the humidities descend upon the canal of the lung, and especially when it is with a cold temperament, then it is necessary that the weak one should first be treated with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it in the Adam's apple at the root of the throat in a depressed place: and beware, lest you penetrate with the cauterization to the throat, nor into the skin, except for a little of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with a cautery at the joint of the neck in the last vertebra, and let the cautery be according to the method which has preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what has preceded, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing for diseases of the Lung and Cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and disease of the lung are from cold humidities, and the weak person has no fever, nor consumption, and not an old disease: then cauterize it with two cauteries above the fork in depressed, gentle, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And cauterize with another on the middle of the chest between the two breasts: and let the cautery be of a tube according to the form which has preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you need to cauterize by pricking with a cautery, which is called a Point, whose form has preceded in the pricking of ear pain: and let the points be from thirty points up to almost a hundred.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what has preceded, until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let the cautery have three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	For it will be lightened with that cautery, when you make with it one of three cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the method of cauterizing for a sprain, in the dislocation of the shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the arm is dislocated due to a cause of humidities, and it does not return to its place in the hour of its return from its dislocation, until it becomes accustomed to returning, then it dislocates from a slight movement, which happens as we have already shown, then it is necessary that you reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then let the weak person lie on his back, or on his healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then elevate the cut which is inside the inner thigh to the upper parts with the fingers of your left hand and if the joint becomes dislocated inwardly.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then apply cauterization to it with two irons.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the cut until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of the cauterization comes with four cauterizations.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when the cauterization is made with a cauterizer having three irons, then the figure of the cauterization is made with six cauterizations and they are irons according to the subtlety of the sensation.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the shape of the cauterizer having three irons.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one is added in this manner, then there are eight cauterizations.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then put on the cauterization ground pork with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then apply a dressing to the wound for tranquility, so that it is not moved for some time, until it becomes strong.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upward and it rarely happens, then cauterize it above the shoulder with a cauterizer for the shoulder or with many punctures.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened, and the moisture is removed, and the weakness is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When there occur in the stomach many colds and humidities, until they extract it from its combination, and multiply the catarrhs to it, and assiduous methods of cure, and do not strengthen: then it is necessary that the weak person lies on his back, and stretches out his legs, and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauterizations, one cauterizer under the shoulder of the chest the size of one finger, with a shoulder cauterizer, and two cauterizations below by the two sides of one cauterizer, until the figure of the cauterizations comes in a triangle.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And let it stretch between both so that they do not join, when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cauterization be a quantity of two thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauterizations be according to this form without addition, and if you want to cauterize with a large cauterizer in the middle of the stomach according to this form, and let the cauterization that is made be one according to the figure of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking him who trembles from this cauterization: and it is, that you mark on the stomach a point according to the quantity, which you want with the encaustic, then cauterize it with the cauterizer of the point: then cure it with the treatment, which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the method of cauterizing a cold liver.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When there occurs in the liver pain from cold and moisture, or from a thick flatulence, until it goes out from its natural passage, and the weak person is cured with what we have said, and it does not benefit him: then it is necessary that the weak person be placed on his back, and marked with encaustic three cauterizations according to this figure, and of the same quantity on the lower liver below the hypocondriac region, where the elbow of the man reaches: and let the space that is between each cauterization be according to the thickness of a finger: and let the cauterization be according to the length of the body straight: and do not press your hand much with the cauterizer.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of what is cauterized be from the thickness of the skin, the quantity of half of it not added: and let the weak person stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If however he is not standing, then let him be lying, who has already extended his legs and lifted his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of a cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you to cauterize these cauterizations with a knife cautery, when there is subtlety and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And beware, lest you proceed to the utmost in cauterization, and the thickness of the whole skin is burned, where the whole body is burned, and it penetrates to the intestines: for the skin there is subtle, therefore know that.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the method of cauterizing apostems of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When there is a flow of matter, and you want to know if that apostem is in the flesh of the liver or in its tunic: then if it is in the flesh of the liver, a weak pain and heaviness come on without sharpness: and if it is in the tunic of the liver, with pain there is vehement sharpness: and you see already, which has wearied the physicians with its cure.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It is necessary therefore that the weak man breathes upon his neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then figure the place of the apostem with a searing cautery: then ignite a cautery that is similar to a radius.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with it one cautery, until the whole skin is burned, and it penetrates to the siphac, until all the sanies come out: then cure it with the cure of flowing ulcers, until it is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not necessary that this species of cautery be used, except by one whose study in the art of medicine is prolonged: and through whose hands these diseases run with experiment many times: then therefore he dares to undertake an operation of this kind.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But to omit it, is better in my opinion.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterizing in the Pleura.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said, a cautery with the roots of aristolochia for a cold Pleurisy in this manner.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is, that you take from the roots of the dry long aristolochia, one root which is longer, that is found on it, and let it be the size of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then submerge it in oil: and set it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery at what is between the junction of the jaw and the neck, and with two small cauteries under the guidance of a little declining towards the part that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And also with two cauteries at what is between the fifth and sixth ribs, declining towards the back a little: and with another cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And with three cauteries at the back: one at what is between the two shoulder blades: and with two cauteries on the two sides of the chest, below the cautery that is between the two shoulder blades.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not necessary that you press your hand with the cautery, but rather that it be on the manifest skin smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some of the ancients have said that there are men who use a cautery made of iron like a probe: and they ignite it, and insert it inside between the ribs, until they reach with it to the same abscess, and the pus comes out: as we have said in the chapter on Abscesses.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with the cautery there is fear that either the weak person dies immediately, or a fistula occurs in the place, for which there is no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	On the method of cauterizing the Spleen Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat an illness of the spleen, with what we have said about curation in the division of illnesses, and your treatment is not effective, then a cautery on it is according to three methods, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Of which one is, that you make three or four cauteries in a line along the length of the spleen according to the figure of the cauteries of Epatus, whose figure has preceded.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between the cauterization a quantity of the thickness of a finger, or a little more.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the method of cauterization be that which we have mentioned in the cauterization of the liver equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cauterizer, and let the patient lean weakly on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of cauterization is: as we have said in the chapter on the dislocation of the shoulder, that there are two cauteries for the ignias, and raise the skin which is in line with the spleen, where the weak left elbow meets: and let your elevation be such that you elevate the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two ignited cauteries by force, until you penetrate the skin from the other side: then withdraw the cauterizer: thus four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cauterizer having three rods.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care that the cauterization, after you apply it, discharges pus for many days: for it is more beneficial than all the rest that have preceded in the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	Of the method of cauterizing in Dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cauterization does not fall into Dropsy, except for the hardened ascleros.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat a dropsical person with the methods of cure which we have mentioned in the division, and the cure is not effective, then it is necessary that you cauterize him with four cauteries around the navel, and one cauterizer on the stomach, and another cauterizer on the liver, and one on the spleen, and two cauteries behind the back between the shoulders, and one in line with the breast, and another in line with the stomach: and let the quantity of the depth of the cauterization be near to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then diminish the open cauterization so that it emits pus over a long period.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And it does not evacuate the weak from cure after cauterization with it, for which two intentions are required to be added to it: and the healing will hasten with the aid of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cautery with which the belly is cauterized, should be a clamp, according to the form that preceded it: and that with which the back is cauterized, should be an olive, according to the form that preceded it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the method of cauterizing the feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When there are apostemations on a hydropic patient, and they are filled with citrine water: it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot in the nocturnal, which is between the ear and the ring finger: and raise your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand: and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the citrine water will flow out, and let the cautery be according to this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make on the two legs two cauteries, one on each leg, and let the cautery be made with the extremity of a knife-shaped cautery: and let the cautery be made according to the length of the leg, one below the knee, and another lower than that, around the middle of the leg: and on every hip make two cauteries: and diminish the open cautery without cure for a long time: so that some water flows out from it: then cure it with the remaining things that we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the method of cauterizing for the relief of the belly.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is a solution of the belly from cold and humidities, until it debilitates the retaining and digesting virtues, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with modes of cure, and not healed: and you see the weak tolerating the cautery of exuberant virtue, then cauterize it with a great cautery on its stomach, according to what preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with a ring-shaped cautery, and four subtle cauteries around the navel, with a subtle clamp-shaped cautery: and a great cautery above the hips, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive moistures and the weak tolerance of that, then cauterize it with a cauterizing iron on the chest, and cauterize all of it with a cauterizing iron: and perhaps you will add two small cauterizations on the stomach near the large one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	It is indeed a profitable treatment, whose benefit does not fail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, and they are from gross, cold, or corrupt humors, and they are treated with what we said in the division, and the treatment is not effective: then cauterize with three cauterizations above the lower vertebra of the back under the almeidati for a short time in a triangular fashion, and cauterize under the navel almost two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is chilled, and his food is not digested, and you see his face breaking out in pimples, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cauterizing iron, according to what came before: and cauterize on his liver, and another on his spleen, with a cauterizing iron on the hip: and leave the cauterized place open for some time: then treat him until he is cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing the tonsils after their excision.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you excise the tonsils, then ignite a cauterizing iron that resembles a staff.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the ignited iron into the excised tonsil: and with your last hand, until the cauterizing iron reaches the opening of the vein, from which blood runs: do that once, or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If therefore there are many tonsils, then cauterize each one with a cauterizing iron according to what we have narrated.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with what constricts them from ointments until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize it with a large cauterization on the alcatin, it is the greatest in treatment of the injury.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the method of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the weak one does not undergo the operation and treatment that we described in its own place, and is deterred by it, perhaps it will be healed with a cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore a fistula occurs to someone, and it becomes chronic, corrupt pus runs out of it, and rotten moistures.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	It is more worthy therefore that which ought to be, that you should probe it with a subtle sound.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the quantity of its depth with the probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then apply a cauterization iron, which is similar to a probe.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert the ignited instrument itself into the same fistula and the quantity in which the nail entered.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat over it the cauterization, until all those rotten bodies are burned, once, or twice, or thrice, according to the quantity of your necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And beware of the burning of the nerve, if it is there, or of the large vein: or if the fistula goes to the body of the bladder, or to the body of the intestine, then beware of all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do that, unless when the fistula is in a fleshy place: and you think that it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then treat the place until it is healed.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If however the place is closed, and matter is cut off from it, and it remains thus for a long time: then know that it is already healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if matter is not cut off from it, then know that it is penetrating, or in its depth there is a rotten mouth, or something like that: whose reminder will come into its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the method of cauterizing the kidney.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys due to cold or gross flatulence and it weakens because of that, then it is necessary to cauterize it on the alumethen over the kidneys, with a cauterizing iron over each kidney, using an iron clamp, whose description has preceded.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we will cauterize it a second time on the same alumethen.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Three lined scars appear.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore they will be more in the lower part of the back.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the method of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When debility occurs in the bladder and softening from cold and humidities, until it does not retain weak urine, then cauterize it on the lower part of the sumen above the bladder, where the hairs of the pubic area begin, and with a cauterizing iron to the right of the sumen, and another to the left of it: and let the length of this cauterization be according to the quantity of a knot of the thumb: and cauterize it with an inferior back cauterizing iron, or two cauterizing irons, if you need them: and let it be according to what preceded, the clavicular cauterizing iron.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the method of cauterizing the womb.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and humidities occur in the womb and it is prohibited from pregnancy because of that, and its menses are corrupted, and the provocation of them is delayed, and pain occurs to it at their arrival, then it is necessary to cauterize with three cauterizing irons around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and a cauterizing iron above the inferior back, or two cauterizing irons: and let the cauterizing iron be clavicular.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the method of cauterizing an ankle in a state of dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous humidities are poured out at the ankle joint, and they become the cause of its exit from its place: and the sign of it is that one leg is prolonged over the other, when they are compared to each other: and the place of dislocation is found empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary that you cauterize the weak part over the ankle joint itself with a similar circular cauterization: after which you mark with a branding iron around the circumference of the joint, as it turns: and so that the joint falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cauterization be one whose shape was described previously in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cauterization is not present to you, then cauterize it with three cauterizations, with a large olive-shaped cauterization: and let the depth of the cauterization be according to the quantity of the thickness of the whole skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On the method of cauterizing for sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the ankle joint, and its causes are cold and humidities: and it is treated with what we said in the division, and the treatment does not work, and it becomes chronic: then it is necessary that you loosen the weak part from gross humors with foul-smelling pills, or with artificial pills, and similar things.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cauterization for it is according to two methods: either cauterization with adhering medicines, or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cauterization with fire is according to many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	Of which one is, that you cauterize over the ankle joint itself with three triangular cauterizations, according to this shape.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make for them a good depth, or a bad one.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let the space that is between all cautery be of the quantity of the thickness of a finger, and let the cautery be of olive.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes indeed the cauterization is made in the middle on the head of the same ankle.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	There are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you apply a cauterization with a circle, whose form has preceded in the cauterization of the dislocation of the ankle, one: so that the little circle contains the whole ankle.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the whole skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cautery for sciatica, when the pain adheres to the ankle itself, and does not extend to the hip and thigh.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends to the hip and thigh, then cauterize it with two cauteries above the hip, above the place to which that weakness points, in which is the pain, and your cauterization above the haunch four fingers towards the woody part for a little while: and let the cauterization be of a knife.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cauterization be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	Which if the weakness indicates that the pain extends almost to the toes of the foot, then cauterize it there where it points with a cauterization of one point, or three, or four, or more, if it needs it.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if it points to pain being under the knee towards the thigh, then cauterize it there with one knife-shaped cauterization.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware in every cauterization of yours, that you do not touch with the cauterization to the point that you burn a nerve, or a large artery, and drag through it above the weak nuisance evil, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I indeed have already seen one and another, of those who cauterized above the haunch, and finished in cauterization, and the thigh was inflamed, until a tumor followed to the foot, and the whole was perforated, and the whole foot was corrupted: then there occurred a loosening of the bowel, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	What if there is pain in two parts at the same time, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And certain wise men have said concerning the cauterization of the ankle, that the manner of this cauterization is thus.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a drill similar to an iron one, whose diameter is half a palm, and let it be at its opening according to the thickness of a date pit, or a little less: and inside that drill let there be a third drill.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let the space that is between all the drills be by the quantity of a thumb knot: and let the drills be open on two sides: and let their height be as a knot, or two knots: and make for them a handle from iron decently fitted to the drills.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then let it be ignited in fire, until it becomes red, and throws out sparks: then let it be placed upon the weak ankle, reclining on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Cauterize it therefore with three round cauterizations in one place.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then leave it for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards apply a plaster with butter: and leave the wound open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, we have used this type of cauterization little, on account of the terror of its appearance: and because we find few who dare to undertake it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	However, it is one of the good cauterizations for him who suffers it, and finds with it its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cauterization with adhering medicines is, that you make two drills having a perforated armlet, into which descends a hinge of its door made from brass or iron, the length of a wall: of which in height there are two knots, or about that.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be a space which is between the two quantities of the thickness of the finger, and let it be open below and above: and let that which they contain be next to one another, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then put it upon the axle of the instrument, while the weak part lies on the healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand strongly upon the axle of the instrument.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between the two circles from warm water, which has been heated with fire for a short time, and hold it for the quantity of an hour's time: and let the weak part tolerate its biting and burning, for it itself finds the biting as fire, until the biting subsides.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then lift your hand with the instrument, and wipe away the warm water from the entire axle with sweet water: then leave it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put upon it butter, until the blackness of the burn is removed: and leave it for some days, and pus will be cured from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	It is indeed the last in joining.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments, until it is healed.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	What if the pain extends to the hip or the leg: make for it a plaster that contains water, according to what you did equally with the axle.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of warm water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the correction of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take of alkaline substance and unslaked lime each one part: grind both, and put them in a new flask, whose lower part is perforated with one small hole, according to the quantity that the radius can enter: and put under the bottom of the flask another flask: and throw upon the alkaline substance and lime sweet water, which submerges both by a finger: after which you press it with your hand with good compression: and leave the flask until sharp water descends in the lower part of the flask.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather all that water and pour it over another lime, and boil, until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be very strongly sharp, which is administered in many operations of medicine, and in the cauterization of the remaining members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Since it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And there are medicines with which they cauterize, also such as tesie and mel of anacard, and lime with soap, so that both may be mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen told of a certain man of the ancients, whose cure was such that it cured the pain of the hip and the vein of the thigh: and he declared its value to be great.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that it did not need another cure, and that he was healed by one means, until he told that he perhaps entered a warm bath, and came out of it already healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is, that it be taken from the juice of the green, and if the green is not found, let the dry recent one be taken, and let much of it be rubbed with some fat, and put on the hip, where there is pain, or the leg, or in the hip, and let it be tied, and left for the quantity of three hours, or as long as he feels a weakening of the sensation of burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then put him into a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore his body becomes very sweaty, put him into the sun.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain returns, and is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that it is not necessary to use a cauterization with these medicines, unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides said that the dung of capers, when with it the vein of the thigh is cauterized, is of service to it: and makes a cauterization in this manner.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Let wool be taken and soaked in old oil, and put on the deep place, which is between the thumb of the foot, and the heel, and is closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry dung of a goat and set it on fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put it on a cloth and leave it until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat it.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease to do that until the sensation is felt up to the knee and the pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called the cauterization of the cow.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the cauterization of pain in the back.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes pain occurs in the back from many causes, either from a fall, or a blow, or excessive evacuation, and similar things, from the infusion of cold and humid matter: and cauterization is not suitable, except in this single case, which occurs from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after the evacuation of the weak with fetid pills, and similar things, so that they are made on the back, where there is pain, three lines according to the width of the alum treatment itself, afterwards you mark with a cautery on each line five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity which comes from the tolerance of the weak by virtue of it: and let the cauterization be done with cauterized points.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauterizations, with a medial clavicular cautery, according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Of the method of cauterizing for the cure of gibbosity.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This disease often happens to small infants.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of this disease in children is: that it happens with a constriction in breathing at the time of elevation and movement: and you find on the last vertebra of the back and its knot, which has already begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When I raise that and make it a tool, then I cauterize it with a cauterizer which is a circle in this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let the cauterization take hold equally over every part of the vertebrae: and if you cauterize around the vertebrae with a pointed cauterizer two or three lines: and let the points be close to one another.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then treat the place until it is healed with what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, lest you apply the cauterizer on the hump that forms during a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the method of cauterizing for gout and pains of the joints.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of the joints are from cold humidities that flow to whichever members of the body, then when pains occur in the feet, it is customary for physicians to call that specifically gout.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore gout caused by cold is being treated with methods of treatment and the pains are not removed, then the cauterizer removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is that you should cauterize him after evacuation around the joint of the foot with many cauterizers: and let the cauterizer be olive-shaped.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose form is this.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you indicate that there are points on the surface of the foot, then make with the cauterizer points.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	Which if the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and it often happens, then cauterize it on every knee with three cauterizers or four on every side, with this same cauterizer for the hip.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If however many are needed for you by this cauterizer, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not insert your hand with the cauterizer, but rather to the thickness of the skin as much.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If however pains ascend to the knees and the back: then administer what we have said from cauterization in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	What if the pains are only in the hands, then punctures around the focuses, as two lines turn.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If however there remains from pain in the fingers, then puncture them, a puncture above every knot and above the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If however pains ascend after days to the elbows or to the shoulders, then cauterize both from every part.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not evacuate the weak from a good regime, from the reception of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regime is made, and the phlegm is evacuated, it will be healed with the help of God together with this cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the method of cauterizing for Hernias.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a hernia occurs in the groin, and the intestine descends or the navel to the testicle, and it is that which begins nearby: then it is necessary to prescribe for the weak to omit eating on their day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let them use lenients, so that feces may descend from their belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and prescribe to him, that he hold his breath, until it comes out, or the navel or intestine appears.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark with a cauterizing iron under the hernia above the bone of the breast, with a mark whose extremities are similar to the middle of a circle at the top of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then ignite the cauterization iron, which is of this form, until it becomes white, and throws out sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or navel to its concavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the servant put his hand over the place, so that the intestine does not come out: and you have now opened between the thighs of the weak, and placed under it a pillow, and one servant over his thighs, and another over his breast who holds the hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then apply the cautery on that same sign, your hand with the cautery standing upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it, until you achieve the mouth with it: or turn it with it twice, if you have not achieved it at first even to the mouth.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe from the exit of the intestine at the time of your cauterization, lest you burn it, and it comes out through that above into weakness or gangrene, or great evil.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not achieve the mouth with the cautery, your operation is of no use.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is fitting that the cautery for infants be subtle, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat with the remaining ointment, until it is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let him be weak, lying on his back for forty days, until the wound is sewn.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is fitting that you put its nourishment for the length of time of its cure, which will soothe its stomach: so that the intestine does not come out at the anus and vomiting.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to get up after forty days, then administer a properly made bandage, and let him hold it for forty more days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And he should be sparing of labor, and filling with food and drink, and violent voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he uses this regimen, thus will he be healed with a complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will speak of the cure for hernias with an incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however hernias occur in the remaining belly, and are beginning, and it is seen that they do not increase, then cauterize the hernia with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let what is burned be one third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then treat it, with that which we have said: and it will not increase.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And now some of the first ones have said: that a hernia should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is marked with a cautery, and a line is applied along the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line is applied to the lower part.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And put your hand in the middle with the cautery on the clavicle.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easiest and best.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	On the method of applying a cautery for pains caused by a fall or a blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When pain occurs in certain members from a fall or a blow, and the pain persists for a long time, and treatment with medicines is of no benefit, then it is necessary to apply a cautery with a pointed cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery of each member be a second cautery according to its size, and its smallness, and its weakness, and its strength, and the location of the twisting and pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is healed by the first cautery, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat over the same place with a cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For it is a custom of these pains that they change from one member to the one that is nearest to it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Wherefore it is necessary to follow them with a cautery until the weak part is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	On the method of applying a cautery for leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	The leprous are sometimes helped by a very large cautery.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the type of leprosy that occurs due to the corruption of phlegm and melancholy: when therefore you use a cautery to treat it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore the leprosy is beginning, and you have treated it with what we said in the division, and it does not decrease, nor does it stop: and you apply on top of the weak part that comprehends the corruption over the entire complexion of it: then apply a cautery to him on the head with five cauteries: one on the middle knot of the head, and a second below that towards the forehead at the end of the hair, and two above the two horns, and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And finally put your hand with the cautery briefly, until it impresses a small impression on the mouth, and the cortices will be dislocated from it: so that the expiration of gross vapors is eased from it, and cauterize with the cautery also over the spleen itself, according to what has preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the leprosy has already spread over the weak part, and appears manifestly: then it is necessary that you cauterize with these cauterizations, which we mentioned in the head, and cauterize over the end of the nose, and with two cauterizations over the two jaws, and with two cauterizations over the vertebrae of the neck, and six over the vertebrae of the back, and one large one over the bone near the base of the tail and one over it, in the same almeidati: and two over the hips: namely one over each hip, and two over the knees: one over each knee, and two over the shoulders, and two over the elbows, and two over the tendernesses of his chest: and cauterize it over every joint, of the joints of the fingers of his hands and his feet: and cauterize over every heel of his feet, and the soles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And beware of the nerves which are above the heel, that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes it is cauterized with a cautery over the bone of the chest, and another over the bone of the stomach, and another over the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you apply the cautery, the greater is the help, and the more beneficial it is.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the weak person does not find pain in the cautery, as the healthy ones do: because his body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauterizations be of a size, and smallness according to the limbs and joints: according to what has preceded regarding the types of irons.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat with a cauterization made from the powder of the herb with honey, and the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	On the method of cauterizing in a stupor.
Caput L.	Head of the Liver
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When any member is in a stupor, and is treated with medicines, and oils, and plasters, and is not healed, then cauterize the stupified member with cauterizations, according to what the size of the member merits or its smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cauterization be shallow into the thickness of the skin for a little while.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with an ointment, until it is healed.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when cauterization is applied for a stupor that occurs to the hand and foot, in the vertebrae of the back at the exit of the nerves which move that member: and the stupor is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But truly let no one presume upon it, except he who is wise in the anatomy of the members and the exit of the nerves moving the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	On the method of cauterizing for Barbers.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Barbers becomes chronic and nothing helps it from the resources of medicine: then cauterize on it with a deep cauterization for a little while, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the whiteness is removed and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the powder of the herb, and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossa, and pigeon's blood, and hyrundin's blood: let one part be of each: mix all these things, and apply them to a cloth, and stick to the place, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	On the method of cauterizing for Cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning and you want to restrain it: then cauterize it with a circular cauterization around its circumference, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	Wise men have said that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	It does not seem to me, for I fear that it will become an ulcer, and I have already seen that happen many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better that it be cauterized around it in a circle, as we have said, or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the method of cauterizing in those who are bald.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has alopecia and it is slow to mature, either because of excessive flux causing it, or because of the weakness of old age, when he is decrepit and has little blood, or because of time and the need to hasten the maturation of alopecia, then cauterize around it with many small cauteries, puncturing many times.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then leave it alone.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten the maturation by itself.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If you want to make a perforation of it with a cautery, then ignite the cautery, which is of this form.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the alopecia, until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be from that which follows, weak, so that the flow of pus may be alleviated.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the method of cauterizing for a corrosive evil.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corrosive is nothing but a corruption in a member that spreads, and it gnaws away the member itself: just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If you see a corrosive in a place that can tolerate a cautery with fire, then prepare many cauteries, small and large, according to what is suitable for the place where the corrosive is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it on every side until you eradicate the entire corruption, and none of it remains in any way.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then diminish it for three days, and apply over the cauterized location burnt sulphur with oil, until all eschars are eradicated, and all corruption.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then treat it with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days healthy flesh is born without corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cauterization over that which remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	The corroding is treated whenever with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	It itself arises in place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	But indeed the cautery with fire is of swifter cure: and I have already spoken of its cauterization with sharp medicine in division: therefore take it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the method of cauterizing in pimples and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	It often happens in the lower parts of the feet this disease: and it is a coarse, foul thing, which harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And the cautery indeed for them is in two ways: the cautery with fire, and the cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As for that with fire, it is like a hollow cautery similar to a feather of a vulture: which is made from iron, according to the quantity that the nail contains on all sides: and let it be subtle in its margins.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then apply it ignited over the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then turn the hand with the cautery around the nail, until the cautery penetrates to the depth of the nail: and diminish it for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then plaster it with woodland marshes, pounded with salt: and diminish the plaster over it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be eradicated from its own roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then treat the place with a generating ointment of flesh, until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	What if they are not turned and often occur on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet: then you will administer to them a cautery with hot water: and it is, that you take a small tube made of bronze, or iron, or of a bird's quill: and put it on the nail, or the outer skin.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then throw into the tube a small quantity of hot water: hold your hand, and you turn it with compression of your hand for a short time, so that the margin of the tube is imprinted on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way to the depth, to the root of the nail: and let the weak one wait for a while on the biting of the hot water for one hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then dispatch it, for the nail is eradicated with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do this with them one after another, until you come to all of them that are on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then treat them after they have been eradicated, with that which generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the method of cauterizing for Tremors.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 56.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.
