Then after the wound had been enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, and it did not obey for exit: then I did not cease to subtly contrive and ingeniously work on it with modes of contrivance, until I began to work on it one day with well-made forceps, according to which the shape of them will be described at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And doctors indeed judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it then, and the wound was consolidated, and the weak one was healed with complete health, and nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of certain arrows, so that you may put a rule and significance on it based on what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with narration, nor does the book comprehend it, and the skilled artisan compares a little with much, and that which is present with that which is absent, and finds a new operation and a new instrument in the descent of extraneous things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed, except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by extraction from the place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite part of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, is either an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place, and is drawn out, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	For if it does not obtrude to the exit from the hour in which it falls, then it is necessary that you should leave it for some days, until the flesh which is in its vicinity putrefies, and its attraction is alleviated, and its egression.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in a bone, and does not obtrude to you at the exit, then leave it also for some days, and move it with attraction and motion every day, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	For if it does not obtrude to you at the exit after days, then it is necessary that you should perforate in the vicinity of the arrow in the same bone on every side with a subtle drill, until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has already proceeded into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those accidents which I mentioned appear from below, then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and leave it, until its condition becomes quiet after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow has penetrated to the brain's membrane, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, unless it is only in the body of a bone, and does not penetrate up to the sifach: and he remains weak for some days, and none of those accidents happen to him: then one should use skill in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	And if it is fixed strongly, and does not yield to attraction: then administer a trephine around the arrow, as I have told you: afterwards cure the place, until it is healed.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	And if the arrow has already been hidden in a location of the body, and is concealed and hidden from sensation: then investigate it with probing.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	And if you feel it, then attract it with certain instruments which are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	And if you are not able to reach it, on account of the constriction of the wound, and on account of the length of the arrow in the depth: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein there: then probe above it, until the wound is enlarged, and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	What if there are to them bones which hold it, then free the flesh fixed in them from every side, with every ingenuity that you can, and ingenuities, if it cannot be above the separation of the flesh in the fracture of the bones, and their dislocation, until it is extracted.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use the dislocation of your hand, with forceps on all parts, until you make it come out: and proceed with utmost subtlety, so that the arrow is not broken, and its attraction and extraction are not made difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	What if you cannot reach it in one hour, then leave it for some days, until those things that are around it putrefy.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then return to it: for indeed the pus will have relieved the contrary condition for you, if on the other hand a flow of blood makes a complication for you, then administer what we said concerning its cure in its own chapter: and guard your skill from cutting the vein, or nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the instrument in every way that is possible to you for the extraction of the arrowhead: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have narrated to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary, that you do when you pull out the arrow, that it be loose according to the shape, according to which it was in the case of the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is of greater advantage.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If however it is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which comes out from the contrary part of another, or now something already proceeds from it to the exterior: or it makes a gibbosity of the extremity of the arrow by sensation from the upper part of the adjacent skin, and you see it standing out: cut therefore over it, and let the cutting be according to the quantity that the forceps can grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it out: for it itself becomes easy to exit.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness, until the arrow impresses on the bone, and enlarges itself: then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for some days: then repeat it, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	What if the wood of the arrow is in it, then drive it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however the wood has fallen, and you want to administer a push: then introduce into it a concave instrument, so that its concavity enters into the tail of the arrow: then drive it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If however the arrow is concave, then drive it out with an instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow will be raised by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	What if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary, that you hollow out the whole flesh, in which the venom is: if it is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it with what connects to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	What if it is an arrow falling in the breast, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side: and is near to that which you touch with the probe, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and beware of the incision of a vein, or a nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then sew the wound, if you see, and treat it, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let there be similar extremities like a bird's beak, which are made like iron: when they grasp above the arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are made of them in many kinds, large and small and medium, according to the quantity of the size of the arrow, and its smallness, and the width of the wound, and its constriction.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of a concave pusher.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of a convex pusher.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the extremity of the convex one, like a rod, so that its entrance is alleviated into the concave arrow, and it is pushed with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of the concave pusher is concave like a bird's feather, so that the entrance of the arrow into it and its impulse are alleviated.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Of the cutting of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 98.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins to be cut, whose course is known in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, in the head are sixteen: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called the two Herbae: and two arteries, which are visible in both temples: and two veins which are in both tear ducts of the eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guide rods, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins that are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins that are bled from in the arms, are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, and it is from the left side: and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the dark one.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the middle vein, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilica and a branch of the Cephalica: and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, and it is placed on the right side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the cord of the arm, and it is placed above the elbow: and it is that from which blood is let, and it is that which appears above the thumb with a visible and clear appearance.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is the vein which is between the ring finger and the little finger: and there are two branches of it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is the one that is under the bend of the thumb on the left side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its place is at the heel on the right side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Ness: and its location is at the heel on the left side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three similar veins.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Of the bloodletting of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The bloodletting of the two veins which are behind the ears is a remedy for old catarrhs, and hemicrania, and sahafat, and bad old headaches.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	The quality of bloodletting is such that it is secondary to which I relate.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, that the head of the weak one should be scraped: and his occiput should be rubbed at the place of the two veins with a rough cloth for good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the weak one should bind his neck with a ribbon, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the places of the ears are behind the ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek them therefore with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there mark with a branding iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the bloodletting knife, and it is that which is called the Incising one.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein in the skin, until the bloodletter reaches the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and skin to the upper parts, and cut the vein with the skin with an incising cut.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or about that, and make come out from the blood as much as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with poultices, and leave it, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now the incision of them has preceded in the beginning of the book, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On the bloodletting of two Arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two Arteries which are in the two temples, bloodletting is a remedy for old migraine: and wrong pride, and frequent eye disease: and an outpouring of overflowing humors to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting them is according to which I relate to you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Let the weak one bind his neck tightly, until the two veins appear with a clear and obvious sensation, and let their pulse be felt under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then apply the septicum with cauterization.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Next raise the skin upwards with your index finger to the upper parts and insert the lancet from underneath and raise the vein to the upper parts.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did with the two other veins, and let the blood flow out according to the quantity of your necessity.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the tight bandage and put your finger on the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterwards put a plaster and poultices on it, and bind it tightly from above with a strong bandage: and leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now the description of them, and their cutting, and their extraction has already been dealt with at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Of bloodletting from the vein of the forehead after the bloodletting of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The justification for bloodletting from the vein of the forehead after the bloodletting of the head is for long-standing facial ailments and for half-headache and redness and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this bloodletting is according to what I will tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient should bind his neck with a ribbon until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument that is called a Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose form is this.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Put the sharp point that is at the head of the Fossorium on the vein, and strike it with a hammer or something else in its manner: and let the blood flow out according to the quantity you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then loosen the bandage of the patient and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a broad lancet.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that the bloodletter be of sharp extremity, but rather of broad extremity, unlike other bloodletting instruments.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And let the bloodletting be second to the transfusion because the mouth is nearby and perhaps the bloodletter will cut it when it is subtle.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the bloodletting of the veins in the two tear ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment of the two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, is for an eye affected with itch and redness: and to purify the eye, and the pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the bloodletting of them is, that it constricts the weak neck with a thread.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then let the bloodletter perform on them: and you stand over its head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the bloodletting be done across to a little length, with a small bloodletter, broad for a little while, for there is no flesh in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the bloodletter is subtle at the extremity, perhaps it will be cut.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let flow out of the blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put a plaster over them, and constrict them one night, and release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the bloodletting of the veins of the Nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The bloodletting of the veins of the Nose is beneficial for acute fever and vehement swelling, and pains of the face, such as half-headache and redness which occurs in the face: especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of its bloodletting is, that it constricts the weak neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold its nose with your left hand, and take a subtle bloodletter, long: and fix it in the middle of the lip, between that which distinguishes the nose according to straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you press your hand with the bloodletter for a little while: and let flow out of the blood according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it for one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the venesection of the veins, according to Guidetti doesn't belong here:  Of the bloodletting of the veins.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The remedy of Guidetti's bloodletting is for constriction of the breath, and catching of leprosy, and melancholy diseases, and impetigo and evil sores, and corroding, that is, herpes and itch.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of the bloodletting of the ears is that it should constrict the weak one under both with a bandage on his neck: and let the artisan stand over the head of the weak person, and the weak person should be sitting on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then let blood from the vein to the length of the bloodletting instrument, for a short time, being ample.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then take out from the blood a quantity tempered, or according to that which you see by necessity which is for it.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise for the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards undo the bandage, and constrict the two veins with a moderate tightness: so that the weak person is not suffocated.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it be until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound will heal.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the bloodletting of the veins, according to Algeberich.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The remedy of Algeberich's bloodletting of the veins is: because it benefits the ulceration in the mouth, and corruption of the gum: and evil sores: and cracks of the lips, and evil sores, also which are in the nose, and its surroundings.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the bloodletting of the ears is, that you should make the weak person sit before you: and constrict his neck with a band.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then uncover his lip, and look at the two veins: of which one is on the right of the lip, and the second on its left: and the sign of each is through blackness of the gums.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that vein is: because around the ears there are small black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Cut therefore on both sides with an oblique incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If however there is doubt in you, and you do not know which of them it is: then attend to the incision of the greater one, and it will become more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do similarly for the two veins which are in the upper lip: and for the most part custom runs with it: and cut the two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Of bloodletting from the vein under the tongue after the bloodletting of the head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The remedy of the two veins which are under the tongue for bloodletting is: that the bloodletting of the head is for the afflictions which are in the throat, and the sickness of the uvula, and the sicknesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bloodletting them is, that you should seat the weak one between your hands before the sun: and elevate his tongue, and look under the tongue from one side one vein, and from the other side another vein: and the color of both veins is inclined towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Bloodlet therefore on both: and beware, lest your last hand be in bloodletting them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps it happens that there is a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins indeed which are bloodlet in the elbow, are in which the custom of bloodletting has run in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And the bloodletting of them is done according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pricking with a broad myrtle needle: or inclining to subtlety with an olive: or cutting with a knife-shaped needle, and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus it is with Alnesil, which converges to the incision.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are broad and subtle types according to the width of the veins and their tightness. The form of the myrtle phlebotomy is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it converges to the opening of hollow veins, full, proceeding, apparent, thick and those which contain gross, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy is of lesser width, and more subtle extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it converges to the phlebotomy of subtle veins, which contain subtle yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On the phlebotomy of Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The Basilica, however, which is one of these three veins for phlebotomy, is a remedy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	For it extracts blood from ailments that are under the throat and neck, from that which follows the chest and stomach: and it converges to the phlebotomist with the phlebotomy instrument, so that he may cut, and is above fear of it, for beneath it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he misses, and touches the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will wound that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Wherefore it is necessary, that the phlebotomist does not puncture with the phlebotomy instrument: but rather cuts with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	What if the Basilica does not appear with a manifest appearance, then it is necessary that you displace it, and change to another, or that you seek some branch of it: or you make a phlebotomy in place of it on the arm vein.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it itself is manifest, and cut it with the phlebotomy instrument Alnesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If however you use the phlebotomy of the same itself, then it is necessary before the tightness of the arm, that you touch the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then apply a cautery on the spot with an incision, afterwards the arm, and cut the vein with a concave section using a phlebotome of Alnebil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And let the cautery not fall through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, with you tighten the ligature, an inflammation in the place which you signed with a cautery, then that inflammation is the inflation of the artery: avoid it therefore.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	For if you see blood at the phlebotomy jumping, like the urine of a child, and it is subtle blood, red: then know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then draw near, and put your finger on it in a long space, afterwards remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If the blood is then cut off (for it is often cut off), then tighten the arm, and release it: and let the weak one be cautious of its motion: and let it be above its fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for some days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If the blood does not stop, and overcomes you: and your medicine is not present at the moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For the extremities of it contract, and the blood is stopped.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the bark of a fig tree, and crush it: take one half, and bind it with a decent stricture over the place of the vein, with a ligature and poultices until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is stopped, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then treat it with that which the remembrance of the place has preceded, powder to stop the flow of blood: and the stopping of its blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the smallness of the place of the wound, and the possibility of a ligature from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the bloodletting of the dark vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The bloodletting of the dark vein is a remedy that draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body; because it is composed of the royal branch and the cephalic branch, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is suitable for the bloodletter to be above the fear from the bloodletting of it, because under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the puncture of the bloodletting and strikes a nerve, numbness occurs in it, and the healing of it becomes difficult, and perhaps it is not healed entirely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to sensation.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If however it is hidden in certain men, and is subtle, and does not show itself: then it is necessary that you place your bloodletting where you will bloodlet with a cut with the Alnesil, and divert the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	For if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The bloodletting of the cephalic vein is a remedy because it draws blood from the head and is useful for the ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein especially, if you wish, that you bloodlet it by puncturing with an olive branch phlebotome, or with a myrtle phlebotome: because it is the saver of all veins, because there is not beneath it an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Truly it is suitable for you at the bloodletting, that you divert with the phlebotome the head of the lancet so much, and seek a thinner place: and it does not harm it, if it is not found with the first puncture, that the bloodletting be repeated over it several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	A true abscess sometimes forms in certain men when not bloodletting is performed on the first percussion, but that abscess does not harm him in any way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the utility of Bloodletting, and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of Bloodletting, however, and its accidents which arise from it, in whose correction you ought to consider.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First therefore it is of that which you ought to know, that bloodletting is not administered except in conservation of health and its preservation and caution against the approach of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that bloodletting is performed on one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the Cephalic and the Fusca and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that bloodletting is done at the beginning of Spring on an empty stomach, and in Summer, and Autumn, and Winter after digestion, when the signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And bloodletting should be done on the first day, or on the third, after three hours have passed from the day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting which is administered in illnesses does not have a determined hour, but when convenience and necessity provoke it, at night or day, and every hour, and every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not fitting that children be bled until fourteen years are upon them.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be bled except from the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should old men be bled who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wants to be bled for any reason: it is necessary that he cleanse his intestines before bloodletting with a gentle clyster, if there is much stool retained in them: so that the veins do not attract from the intestines putrid and harmful superfluities to the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should blood be let from a patient who is suffering from nausea, that is to say, disgust; nor one who is drunk or vomiting from intoxication, until that is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor the weak with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let blood be taken again after colic passion, and vomiting, and flux of the belly, and excessive coition, and labor, and exercise, and wakefulness, and fasting, and anything that dissipates virtue from the bodily or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors beforehand, whether the blood is thick with foods and drinks and medicines, if it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let a bath be taken, if nothing prevents it, or let exercise be used, so that the blood may be thinned.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And let bloodletting be applied to his chest, around the third day, as we have said: and take care, that his chest may be evacuated on that day from all bad animal accidents: such as anguish, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, and pain, and excessive coition, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him have present the things with which usage has created a habit in men from aromaticity, and fragrance, and rubbing and similar things to the quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the bloodletter sit on a cushion, which is higher than the cushion of the one to be bled: afterwards let him draw out his arm, and rub it with his hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then let him tie the bandage with a strap, and turn it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the tightening be moderate, because when the tightening is uneven, or excessive in tightness, then it prohibits the flow of blood: and in looseness, it also prohibits the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, it is necessary that the hand of the bloodletter rubs his hands together, until the veins become swollen and are apparent to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the bloodletter shall wipe the vein with a little oil, belonging to himself or an old one.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he shall place his index finger of the left hand on the vein under the location where he wants to perform the bloodletting, so that the vein does not escape and the stroke is made.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For there is a vein which when you come upon it during bloodletting slips away like a bowstring: and of them there is one which is full of wind: and when you place the bloodletting instrument on it, it contracts under the blade, and the bloodletter is deceived, and the vein does not show itself: and if it does show itself, it is constricted: therefore it is necessary that the bloodletter be steady, and be solicitous in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he shall put down the bloodletting instrument.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then the vein is exposed from one stroke, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then he shall try again another time in that location, or above it with speed, provided the place is not damaged.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	What if it becomes inflamed, or becomes weak and feeble, then let it be for a day, or two days: and do not constrict the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps heat will attract the inflammation.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And let him not enter a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he shall repeat the bloodletting, if it is loved.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	What if the opening is small, or the blood flows subtly and thinly: and so that not a quantity of blood escapes which is excessive: then he shall try the bloodletting instrument in the same opening, according to what is right, and add a little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And let him do it with speed, before the place becomes inflamed, for an inflamed place is a problem for many men during a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If then you see it already suppurating, then do not repeat on it altogether, for it does not excuse anything with you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something upon it from the dregs of oil: because it will alleviate the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than the oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the dregs of oil in all your bloodletting, which you let blood to prohibit the flow of blood: and they call it Tyriac Alfarach, and Sagzenea, when it is put from one of them on the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood is refined and dissolved, when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	What if it happens in the place of bloodletting a large abscess, for it often happens, especially to him who is not accustomed to bloodletting except by chance, or is opening a small vein, then quickly and put on the place a sponge soaked in hot water and salt: and bind it for one hour: because it will dissolve.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do that after the blood has come out from the same vein, when its flow is complete, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	What if something black or green remains in the place after days, it does not harm: and if you wish, put on it some aloe, or a solution of myrrh: or something from the juice of mint, that is, calamint or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And often indeed abscesses and swellings occur with bloodletting of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore put your hand on it, then if you find softness with compression on it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Beware therefore, that you put on it something of what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood of the artery will flow from it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make for it an plaster with that in which is astringency, so that the place may be indued.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then cure itself with the remainder of the treatment, until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary, that you extract from every man blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color overcoming the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it exit, until it becomes red: and similarly if you see it thick: then let it exit, until it becomes subtle: and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and needs extraction of blood twice, that the phlebotomy of the vein be amplified, and the phlebotomist be skilled: and in him who is weak, let it be to the contrary of this.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary, that he extract it in the veins, and that the opening be narrow: and better that which is administered in the phlebotomy of the vein is, that it be a cross-section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this mode of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of the nerve: and it is more to be praised, and safer than phlebotomy by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is customary to faint at phlebotomy of the syncopis, it is necessary that he eat before phlebotomy moderate bread infused in water of granate or of musk, if it is warmed: and extract for him from the blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if it is a cold complexion, then let him receive before phlebotomy bread infused in syrup of myrrha, or in syrup of honey aromatized with spices, or in syrup aromatized with perfume.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	What if it happens a faint at phlebotomy, and is the cause of its exit of much blood: then it is necessary, that he take in drink water of flesh, and subtle perfume syrup: and that he use aromaticity with galbanum, and that his breast be lined with it: and that he use the remaining things which we said in the division in the chapter of faint from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to purify his arm and release his blood secondly: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is due to abundant evacuation, and the virtue of it is weak, that he should release blood little by little according to the quantity of virtue in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Who indeed wishes to purify his arm and release his blood secondly, and his body is strong: then let him do that after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to attract blood from his body to the opposite part to which it inclines: it is necessary that he should be purified on the second day, or on the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whom there is indeed much blood already heated and sharpened, and it causes fever to occur: it is necessary that blood should go out from it in a single vein, and a large quantity be extracted from it: and the opening be widened until syncope occurs: after which you have observed all conditions of phlebotomy: and that you place your hand on his pulse at the course of the blood, so that death does not occur in place of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For it often happens, when the phlebotomist is ignorant, and negligence occurs.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when the vein has been closed, and the second release of blood is to be made, with the orifice of the vein already closed, and the exit of blood becomes difficult, that it should be pressed upon with violence, and the curved needle extended quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a grievous evil, leave it alone, until a second phlebotomy is made.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with acuteness of phlebotomy that which has coagulated from the blood at the orifice of the vein, and put on it something of salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put on it something of tyriac alfarch or sageena, and apply it with gentle compression, until the blood goes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If the vein has already become varicose, then leave it, and do not touch it, until the aposteme has settled.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	What if necessity provokes to let blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either perform phlebotomy on it above that place, or on another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arms are bled at the places of the Funis, and Basilica, when they are not found, and are hidden, because it is composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is, that an weak hand should be put into warm water, until it becomes red and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then let it be constricted above itself with a bandage of moderate tightening.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then let the phlebotomy be done across gradually, not across the width, nor along the length: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be where you will phlebotomize above the joint of the hand for a short time.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	What if the flow of blood is stopped, then put the hand again in warm water, and let the blood flow in the water, until you obtain your necessity.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If however it is in the days of summer, then you should be spared from putting the hand again in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And for the most part, the flow of blood is put into warm water in winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is salvation to all veins, because there is neither a pulse beneath it, nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of the right Salvation vein is conferring with the liver's illnesses.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is, that you constrict the hand with a bandage, or your hand, after you have put it into warm water, until the vein becomes inflated, and shows itself to the sense.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then let the bloodletting be done by crossing over.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it entirely, it will not harm it in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful, lest you wound your hand with the lancet.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then put the hand into warm water, and let the blood flow out into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not put it in warm water, the blood coagulates in the opening of the vein, and is prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have extracted the amount of blood necessary, then put oil and salt on the vein, so that it does not close quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly it is necessary to do with every constricted branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The justification of its bloodletting from the left hand is that it contributes to diseases of the spleen: and do similarly in its bloodletting as you did in the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The justification of bloodletting from the saphena vein is for diseases which are in the lower part of the body, such as diseases of the matrix, and retention of menses, and weaknesses of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the hips and thighs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of its bloodletting is that the weak foot should be immersed in warm water: and friction should be made on it until the veins are swollen: and bind above the joint of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the place of the vein is near the heel, appearing towards the thumb: and many branches ramify from it on the sole of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore perform bloodletting on its larger branch, or near the heel at its collection: because it is better and more healthful.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	For if you perform bloodletting on the sole of the foot, then beware of the nerves which are under it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your venesection where you want to make an incision across it, as if you wish to cut it, and let the cutter be a NESIL.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If on the other hand the flow of blood is impeded, then soak its foot in warm water, and let the blood run into it until it evacuates.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	What if the bloodletter misses the vein at the first time, then let him repeat with venesection towards the upper parts for a little while, for the location is safe, and you will not take harm from it when you cut a nerve, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel on the wooded side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the indication for venesection of it is, for pain of the hip, when it is because of hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of its venesection is, that an weak person should enter the bath and be bound: and let the leg be constricted from the side of the hip up to above the heel four fingers, with a subtle long thread: for it does not appear unless because of that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then venesect it according to whatever ingenuity is possible for you, or according to the crossing: and it is better, or that you cut it with an incision, or that you section it.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is salvageable, and it itself is hidden very much in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	What if you do not find it, and it does not appear to the sense at all: then venesect some branch of it, and it is that which appears on the back of the foot, and turned towards the ear: and beware of the nerve, and make the blood flow in quantity as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the constriction, and put a bandage over the place of venesection, and constrict the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It will heal quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Of letting blood, and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Cauteries are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And bloodletting is done in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and the extraction of blood: and the other is bloodletting without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this bloodletting which is without scarification, is according to two methods.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the bloodlettings that are administered with scarification and the extraction of blood, are fourteen places in the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the bloodletting of Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and the bloodlettings of Alhagdahim, and they are two sides of the neck from both parts together: and the bloodlettings of the jaw, and it is under the jawbone in the lower mouth: and the bloodlettings of the two spaulders: and the bloodlettings of Alachosos above the end of the tail: and the bloodlettings of the two elbows, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and the bloodlettings of the two thighs: and the bloodlettings of the two hams.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And bloodletting indeed does not extract blood from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of that, no virtue falls from them, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor is it necessary to administer bloodletting, either with fire or without fire, in any of the diseases that occur from overfullness, until the whole body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	Which if necessity calls for bloodletting because of disease or because of habit, let us administer it at every hour at the beginning of the month, at the end of it, and in the middle of it, and at whatever time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	What is it, that which is from humans who when blood is multiplied in them to the point that it needs extraction through venesection, finds in its head a heaviness and swooning.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And there is one of them who finds fullness and redness in his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And there is one of them who finds itching in his face and forehead, and darkness and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there is one of them who scratches the place of his venesection.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there is one of them whose sneezing is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there is one of them who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or it gathers on his tongue, and he spits out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there is one of them whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there is one of them who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and killings, and wounds, and things that are similar to those.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see any of these things, and it is specifically in the third quarter of a month, we prescribe that venesection be done, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The indication for venesection of the neck is: since it brings about heaviness in the head, and what flows to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is necessary that it be after purging of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this venesection is in place of bloodletting of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted that it be used by one who is of a cold complexion, or in whom there is a flux.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings to him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of that, it is not fitting that the elderly use it, and those in whose head there are cold ailments.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	He who does it frequently over it, brings about for himself forgetfulness.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And on account of that it is necessary to warn the person performing the procedure, that he should place his hand with the veins for a short time in a lower position, fearing the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The application of the cup or Alkehel is in place of phlebotomy of the dark vein and the royal vein, and on account of that it brings together the spasm and constriction of breathing, and the fissure of the instrument of breathing, and coughing, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary that the cup of Alkehel be applied for a short time, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The application of the cup, indeed, brings together pains that occur in the head, and diseases of the eyes, and half headaches, and perforations, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is in place of royal phlebotomy.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to warn the one performing the cupping, that he should not press his hand with the scarification, so that he does not cut an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The application of the cup under the chin brings together ulcers in the mouth and corruption of the gums and similar things from ailments which are in the mouth: and it is in place of the phlebotomy of the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The application of the cup to the shoulders brings together the disease of alchafacham, which occurs from congestion and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The application of the cup to the inner parts of the two armpits brings together the substitution of phlebotomy of the three veins, the royal, the dark and the cephalic: because it itself attracts blood from all those small veins which are in the flesh: and those small veins attract from other thicker veins, until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary to warn the one performing the cupping, that he should not proceed far with the scarification: because the place is bare of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	A poultice is applied to what is swollen above the anus, and it relieves hemorrhoids and lower ulcers.
