Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary to instruct the applier of the poultice that it should be large and made of air, because the location requires strong suction, and subtle poultices are easily torn, and a large scarification should be scarified.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Poultices of the legs diminish with manifest diminution: because they draw blood from the whole body, and relieve old pains in the kidneys, and uterus, and bladder: they provoke menstruation, and relieve a flux, and amenorrhea: and they take the place of phlebotomy of the two saphena veins, and aloxocheni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they greatly weaken the body, and cause syncope to occur in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the benefit of poultices of the vein behind the knee is similar to the benefit of poultices of the two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of poultices is that you should put a poultice in a vacuum, and draw with tempered suction: and you should not prolong the positioning of poultices, but rather put them quickly, and remove them quickly, so that humors come to the place equally: and do not cease to repeat and continue this, until you see the place already red and inflamed, and the appearance of blood appears: then scarify, and repeat the suction little by little.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who is of tender flesh and rare pores among men, it is necessary to scarify the place once, no more: so that the location is not ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the applier of poultices to amplify the scarification and make it a little deeper: and to temper the suction with facility, speed, and its own motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	What if there is thickness in the blood, then it is necessary to scarify the place twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In this case, what is first investigated is the subtlety of blood and its thinness: and in the second, what is investigated is the scrutiny of extracted coarse blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If indeed the blood is very foul, then let there be made a third scarification: so that it may follow the last.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And in the end, when we wish to extract blood little by little, or for a short while, one scarification is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	What if we wish the extraction of much blood, we make many scarifications.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is coarse: then it is necessary that there be made a deep scarification: and the limit of equality in the scarification is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that thing which ought to be administered from oils at the placing of the bandages, and what the bandage covers.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that case in which the skin is coarse, hard, dark, and its pores are constricted, it is necessary that the places of the bandage be anointed with oils which are opening, loosening, resolving: if it is in the summer season, such as is the oil of cloves, or the oil of violet, or the oil of sweet almonds, or the oil of the seed of gourd.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the winter season, then the oil of narcissus, or the oil of lily, or the oil of chamomile, or sabbatical: and similar things.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If indeed the excess is coarse, cold: then let the oil be bitter, or the oil of balsam, or the oil of abeny, or the oil of dill: and their similars.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If indeed the bandage is of large pores, of tender flesh: then it is necessary that it be prohibited from oil, and it is necessary that these places of the bandage be washed after the bandaging with rose water, or with cold water, or with solatri water, or with gourd water, or with purslane water: and their similars.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of much humidity, should wash the ventoses with vinegar, or with water of myrtle, and sumach: and similar things.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whose superfluities are gross, should wash his ventoses with old wine, or with water of samsuc, or decoction of anet, or camomile: and similar things.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is fitting that the ventosation should be received in a bath, or in a dressing room of a bath, and it is fitting that it should be administered after the exit from the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not fitting that anyone should sleep after ventosation.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is it that one ought to be governed by, the Ventosed or the one who will be bled before ventosation.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that it is fitting that you consider first: then if the Ventosed or the one who will be bled is choleric, and there are conquering on his blood acuteness and inflammation: then it is fitting that he should receive cooling things, such as granulated mucilage: and also an enema with vinegar and lettuce, and secaniabin, and iuleb: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And let his food be soft porridge, and meat of boiled eggs, and seasoned foods with verjuice: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And whose complexion is cold, it is fitting that he take in a drink syrup of honey, or of almiua, or alsecaniabin made from seeds: and let him take fragrant wine, which is between old and new: and let him be prescribed to use a small amount of food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And let his food be soft porridge, and cane sugar: and peas, that is, small birds: and the soft porridge of doves.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is fitting that the drink on the day of ventosation and phlebotomy should be more than the food: and it is fitting that there should be given in a drink to certain men at the third hour alfaroch, or medicine from musk, that is, muscad, or alesselithe before ventosation: and before phlebotomy, or after: so that the principal members may be comforted, and the blood may be thinned.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it should not be taken in a hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On inflammation without incision.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Inflammations which are without incision, are those that are applied on the liver, and spleen, and gout, and on the navel, and the umbilicus, and the kidneys, and the groin: because these members do not tolerate incision on themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought for through them, unless there is an attraction of blood from one member to another member: as we apply a plaster on the breasts in case of a flow of blood from the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to dissolve a cold inflammation from a member into another member: as we apply a plaster on the abdomen and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it rarefies the member, and warms it, and removes the pain for that reason, because it resolves that inflammation.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	And it is also applied on the kidneys, when there occurs in them a stoppage or a stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For by the virtue of its attraction it perhaps opens up the blockage, or extracts the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And it does similarly when it is applied on the liver and spleen for a tertian fever in both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these plasters should be given to those who are with incision, only so much.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered with warm water full in cases of pleurisy: and that is, so that the plaster is filled, and is large, with hot water alone, or with water in which herbs that are suitable have been decocted.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of a plaster administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its opening be two fingers, according to which we form it: and its quantity in depth be half a palm: and let there be on its side in the place which is around the middle of it, a small hole, according to the quantity that the needle enters: let it be made from copper or brass, of thick edges, smooth, equal, polished: so that it does not harm the member at its position on it: and let there be in its middle a transverse rod of copper or iron, where the candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this large suture is made, greater than we have described, and a little less, according to the ailments and age of the one who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For there are different sutures for children and for the thin, than for men and those with large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of applying this suture with fire on the member, is that you set alight a small piece of linen with fire from a lamp or a small candle made of tallow: and place it above the middle of the transverse rod which is in the middle of the suture: so that the fire burns around the lower part of the suture, so that the body of the weak person does not get burned.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then it is placed on the member: and the finger is above the hole that I mentioned, until when we hold the suture: while we press, we remove the finger, and vapor will come out over that hole, and the suture will be loosened immediately.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then apply a small piece of linen to the fire according to its size, and remove it, if you press on it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the suture that is administered for the ailment of dropsy with water, there is no transverse rod, nor hole: and it is not administered, unless it is filled with water, and placed on the member only.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this suture, the larger it is, so that it can hold much water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	Of the suspension of bloodletting.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter 99.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Bloodletting is not administered to many, unless it is in those members where the application of sutures is not possible, due to their smallness, such as the lip, and gums, and similar things.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in a member stripped of flesh, such as the finger, and nose, and similar things.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: that you should use bloodletting from the veins that are in clear and clean waters, free from corruption.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they should be soaked day and night in fresh water until they are softened and nothing remains in their stomach.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body should be treated at first with bloodletting and with applications to the belly.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then the weak member should be cleansed until it becomes red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Afterwards they will be placed upon it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are filled and fall, and it is possible to suck the place with an application, then it is almost the end of the treatment: and if not, then wash the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then with much water, and rubbed, and squeezed out.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	What if the flow of blood is prolonged after a fall of the blood vessels, and it is that which flows back: then soak a linen cloth in cold water, and put it on top, until the flowing back is cut off.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	What if the blood increases, then powder on it aseh powder, or alum, and similar things from astringents: until the blood is cut off.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or they will be placed on the place half-cooked broad beans: and left until the beans stick to the place, for the blood is cut off.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary if a repetition of bloodletting is needed, when it is possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If however the blood vessels are forbidden from suspensions, then the place should be cleansed with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or apply a sharp point to the places, until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they should be applied, for as soon as they feel something from the blood, they stick at once.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When therefore you use them so that they fall, powder on them something from powdered aloe, or salt, or ash: and they will fall at once.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	The end of the second part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	The Book of Surgery of Albucasis Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	A general discourse on restoration and dislocation, and the cure of twisting, and similar things.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is also often necessary in the art of Medicine, and it is the restoration of fractures and dislocations of accidents in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know, O sons, that the foolish medical men and the common people mock this chapter, and who have never inspected any ancient book, nor read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason it happens that this method is deprived of the sciences in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I did not find anything good in it at all, and I would not have attained what I attained if not for the length of reading ancient books, and study beyond understanding them, until I extracted the knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I adhered to experimentation and study for the duration of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you from it in this Chapter all that my knowledge contains: and on which my experimentation has passed, after I had shortened it for you, and freed it from the occupation of prolongation, and shortened it at the end of shortening, and showed it at the end of declination: and formed in it many forms of instruments that are administered in it, when it is with the addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	A sum and collection from the being of fractures of bones, from which a preliminary necessity is, before we begin the remembrance of fractured members, and diverse ones, if each one.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is fitting that we say in the prologue of this Chapter, the sum of the discourse and chapters, for the understanding of which the artisan is compelled at first to stand on their truth: namely so that you, and those who are prompt, may know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say, therefore, that when a fracture or dislocation or torsion or fall happens to someone, then it is necessary first to bleed him and/or to treat him, both at the same time if nothing prevents it, such as weakness of strength, or if he is one of those persons who has a fever, or an old decrepit man, or if it is a time of violent heat or of violent cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then let him be content with his food of cooling herbs, and flesh of birds, and of fish: and prohibit wine, and fat meats, and fill him with foods and every food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until when you are secure from the hot aposteme, and you do not fear the effusion of material to the member: then let the weak man return to his first regime with which his habit was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When, therefore, the broken bone begins to be restored, then it is necessary that the weak man be fed with nutritious foods of much nourishment, thick, heavy, in which there is viscidity: such as food made from cooked wheat with water, and rice, and cabbage, and feet and hocks of geese, and eggs, and fresh fish: and thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For with this regime a consolidation of the fracture happens more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in early old age and decrepit, it is not possible that they knit and consolidate according to their nature always, because of the dryness of their membranes: and they consolidate and knit which of them are at the end of softness, such as the bones of little boys.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Truly, however, nature joins to the broken bone from every part something like glue, in which there is thickness, with which it adheres and binds itself, until they knit together and bind together, until they come to the end of strength and firmness, as they were at first, until nothing prevents them from their operations: and for this reason it is necessary that you put nourishing food for the weak man, in which there are thickness, and viscidity, and grossness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And you should know that there are different types of fractures, according to the diversity of organs, because a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head bone, and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the back bone, and similarly all the other organs are different from one another, and I came with remembrance of each species of fracture exposed in its distinct Chapter, separate from another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the species of bone fractures also differentiate among themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	For it becomes a fracture that is curved, besides which stars occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And when a fracture occurs according to the length of the bone, and its fractures are jagged, that is, stars, and additions proceed, as they are in a reed, when it is adapted to a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And not proceeding, and it is a fracture with a wound and disruption in the head, and it is a small fissure fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And each species has its own ingenuity, or proper instrument for its restoration, according to which comes the remembrance of it, distinct in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from that which the fracture of the bone is recognized, is its twistedness and its own prominence: and its appearance to the senses, and its sound when you press it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When therefore the twistedness is not apparent in its place, nor sound upon your touch when you touch the bone with movement, nor does the weak one find great pain: then there is no fracture there, but it is possible that there be a twist or small fissure: therefore it is not necessary to move it with hand and compression at all, but rather put on top of it from medicines, which remembrance came after the moment that it is suitable for the place: then let the strict bandage be tightened.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you should know that the place when it is curved and splits into two, besides which stars occur in it, nevertheless every part is moved away from its comparison: then it is necessary for you to begin from your hour to rectify it, equalizing it before hot apostema occurs to it.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	If a hot abscess happens to it, then leave it for some days until the abscess quiets.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then treat it equally according to whatever method is possible from gentleness and ingenuity.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And you should know that the restoration of it and its equalization is easier than of a bone, in which occur fractures.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then bind it, according to what the memory of it will indicate to you.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If there are fractures in the bone, then extension of this broken member is necessary from two parts, if it is the hand or foot: or with your hand, if it is a small member: or with two cords, or with a cord and a hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be where you place the member on an equal place, according to its natural figure, until when the parts of the broken member are extended: then try, that you make those additions return with all ingenuity, and according to whatever method you can in their places: and beware according to your strength, that pain or injury does not happen to the weak one through your operation: and try according to your strength, that you apply one of the two bones with its companion, according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that time, that you touch and feel it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something different there, correct it, and equalize it according to the quantity of your ability.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware of violent extension and strong compression, as many stupid ones do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For they often cause a hot abscess to happen through their operation, or a contraction in the member: as we have already seen that from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then connect after equalization, and decent operation, and straitness of that member, and quiet, and tranquility: and warn the weak one above it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And let it heal so that it does not move during the time of its watchfulness and its sleep with regard to its revolution and its agitation and with regard to its ejection and all its movements with its final strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And let it heal so that the position of the limb is not a position in which pain follows.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	Which is, that when it feels pain or injury in the disposition of the limb's position, then it is necessary to change it to a different disposition from that in which it does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And let it heal with that, so that its position is equal and straight, so that crookedness does not occur in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the fracture of the broken limb is according to which I will describe.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that fractured limbs differ in their smallness and size and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Therefore, those of them which are small, such as the arm and finger and elbow and similar things, then it is necessary that there be a wrapping of soft cloth, fine.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	Those of them which are large, such as the hip and thigh, it is necessary that there be a wrapping on them of broad, hard cloth.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	For a broad bandage connects the large limb and binds it on every side with equal constriction, so that it does not press upon it unevenly.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then begin after your adjustment to put a plaster suitable for it on the soft cloth over the place of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to wrap a bandage over the place of the fracture itself with three or four wraps, according to what the limb deserves, and bind your hand firmly with the bandage for a short time.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go up with it to the upper part from the place of the fracture and bind less tightly than was your constriction, with which you bound the fractured place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then stretch yourself with an involution from the place of the fracture for a little while, and gradually soften the stiffness, until you take from the healthy place a large thing.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another cloth, and involution it again over the place of the fracture with involutions.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Afterwards lead with an involution to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your operation be on the tightening of the involution and its softening, according to what we said in the first involution above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then put between the involutions a piece of flax or cloth, with which the crookedness of the fracture is equalized, if there is crookedness in it: and if not, you do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then involution another cloth over it.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Afterwards equal the stars made from the plaster directly over these involutions, if there is not an inflammation in the place, nor a hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If however there is an inflammation or an abscess in it: then put on it what will calm that abscess and take away the inflammation: and leave it for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then bind over it the plasters at that time.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the plasters be from the middle parts of latten cane, scraped, formed wisely: or let them be from wood from which are made cribs, which are made from pine or gerahid, that is, branches of palm, or calingi: and let the width of each plaster be according to this form, and this same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	Truly it is necessary, that the plaster which is put on the same fracture, be a little thicker and wider than the other plasters: and the length of the plaster be according to what is suitable for the member from its size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then bind over the plasters with another cloth, according to the first tightening, the same.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind from above with threads in the middle, according to what we said about the dressing: and it is, that your dressing should be above the place of the fracture more: and the more it is elongated from the fracture, the dressing is less.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is fitting, that the threads should be moderate in thickness and fineness, and should be of soft flax.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the threads are thick, as I have seen in the operation of foolish surgeons who put their threads of flax twisted into strings, it is a great mistake: for the dressing falls with them beyond the quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And very fine threads are not suitable either: for you will not achieve through the dressing with them that which you wish.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it is not fitting, that it should be between stitch and stitch less than a finger.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	What if a weak person is injured by the ends of the stitches after the dressing on healthy places: then put under them from soft lint or wool, anointed with salve, until nothing is injured from that.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When, however, there is a fracture with a wound, and a disruption occurs in the skin, I will come to it with discussion of it in the second chapter according to its uniqueness.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And know that not every broken member needs to be bound with stitches from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	What is, that when the member is large, it is not fitting to put stitches upon it, unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your security from the event of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the method of plasters, with which the ancients restored, which are put on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	The method of a common plaster abbreviated, restoring a fracture, suitable for many complexions, especially for women and children: for it is from that upon which neither heat nor cold prevails.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is, that you take from the powder of the millstone, and it is the marrow of the flour which hangs in the walls of the mill near the motion of the mill: and you knead it as it is, except that you mix it with the white of the egg: and you put its confection not thick, nor subtle.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	Another method of plaster for restoring a fracture, and a dislocation, and a twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take mastic and laudanum and acacia and elecampane and mugwort: and juice, of each a similar amount, myrrh and aloe of each a similar amount, and of electam a third of that, let all be pounded, and sifted, and mixed with water of electam: or with the white of an egg, if the plaster is applied to a weak complication.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition, it restores broken bones quickly, and confirms many men.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	Another method of plaster, which also confirms fractures and twists.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take mugwort and mastic and white plant, of each a similar amount, myrrh and aloe of each a similar amount, acacia a sixth part, Armenian bolus a twentieth part, let all be pounded with much grinding, and sifted, and kneaded with water, or the white of an egg: and administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	Another method of plaster for joints, and bones separated from their places: and it calms the accidental pain to them, and the cracking of bone, and the fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Let lanolin be applied, and submerged in vinegar, and oil cooked: and put upon the place.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this plaster there is not virtue of restoration, but it is good for calming a hot abscess: and it properly expels pains.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	Another method of plaster, which restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take the leaves of the fig and the leaves of the poppy, and pound all, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	The method of abbreviated plaster, administered for the restoration of the fracture of a bone: and when you wish to resolve a remaining postulate.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take the root of the altea, and chamomile, and the flowers of violets, and the powder of the herb, all in one portion: pound all, and mix with wine, if the member is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If the member is hot, then mix it with water of moist coriander, or with water, and apply it thereto.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	Another method of a stronger plaster for resolution, than the first one, when there occurs a hard postulate during the restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take the root of the altea, and seed of flax, and balsam, and melilot, and samsuch, and flowers of violets, and chamomile, all in one portion, pound all, and mix with water of willow, or with sweet water, or with wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	All that according to the heat of the member, and the tranquility of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates indeed did not say in his book that anything should be put on a fractured member for its restoration, except a cerate made from wax and oil: none other: and he described it as being a mean between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	But Galen used to put on a fractured member for its restoration things, in which there is an exciting of heat, such as myrrh, and aloe, and frankincense, and similar to them from those which we have described.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	A method of plaster that is useful for a wound and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take mugwort, and cichory, and cut human hair, or dove's wings, and altea, and salt in equal parts: pound, and sift, and mix: and make from it a plaster.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The quantity however according to which it is necessary that the ligature remains and then is dissolved, is, that you consider then, if not severe pain occurs, nor itching, nor the fractured bone moves from its place: then you do not resolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If there happens to it in the place intense itching, or troublesome pain, or swelling: then hasten and dissolve it within the hour, and remove the plaster from it: and take a soft cloth, or a marine sponge, moist: and submerge it in warm water, and wash the place with it, until the itching is stilled, and the pain is assuaged.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then put on it a wool cloth soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind over it for one night, until you are secure from the hot abscess, and the inflammation of the limb is stilled, and its pain is removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat it to a subtle binding and small plaster: and do not bind it with your first constriction, but subtly, until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the abscess and redness and pain and swelling and all accidents are entirely removed, and you apply plaster and binding, then repeat it as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If none of the things we have spoken of happen to the limb, then do not dissolve it unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it is left for twenty days, all of that which appears to you from the solution of the limb, as we have said, until when the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh approaches over it: add then also in the binding more than your whole first binding: and add also in the thickening of the weak body, according to what its remembrance has preceded.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If you see the place of the fracture is already becoming dry and withered more than it should be then you should know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Apply a warm poultice to it at every place where you reduce the fracture and let it be thus for three days, and alleviate the tight bandage for a little while.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Through this operation nourishment runs to the limb and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	What foolish restorers do when a limb is fractured and not restored at first as it ought to be, but instead is restored according to its deformity, is an error in their operation and a great danger: and if it were correct, the ancients would have said so in their books and would have operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I have not seen any trace of them at all, and it is better that it is not done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	On the fracture of a wound on the head.
Caput III.	Chapter Three.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The species of fractures are various and its shapes are many: and the causes of it are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For there is a fracture that occurs from a blow with a sword: and the blow removes the bone as far as it reaches to the siphac, which is under the bone, just like an axe does in wood: and because of this it is named this species of fracture Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the sword strikes a part of the bone and strikes its surface, and the cut does not penetrate to the end of it: and this species of fracture is named Kalan, that is, Absolute Separation.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there is a wound of two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And there is a fracture that is a crushing or bruising: and its cause is a blow with a stone, or a fall on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also either penetrating, which now approaches the periosteum, which is under the bone: or it is on the surface of the bone: and there is a wound of these two fractures also, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And there is a fracture which is hidden in the bone in the fineness of a hair: and it is a small fissure, and because of that this type of fracture is called Capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And there is a fracture which occurs from a fall, or a blow with a stone, and similar things, which cause the lamina of the bone to penetrate to the interior, and it becomes concave in that place: just as happens to the caldarii of copper, when a blow occurs to them, and a part of them penetrates to the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And it happens most often in the heads of moist bones, such as are the heads of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And there are for all these types of fractures treatments separated, and I will come with a reminder of the whole thing in its own place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these types of fractures by detection upon them, and an inquiry into them with probes, and the removal of corrupted flesh which is upon them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The species of Capillary fracture is recognized by this, that it is detected on the bone, and wiped away, and anointed upon it with a plaster: for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In the treatment of a fracture, consider first the accidents of the weak person: then if you see from the accidents something that signifies a manifest sign of fear, such as vomiting of bile, and stretching, and loss of intellect, and interruption of voice, and fainting, and acute fever, and protrusion of the eyes, and redness of them, and similar things to these from accidents in many conditions, without doubt it is not cured: and if you see accidents not terrifying you, and you hope for health: then begin the treatment of it.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	Which is, if the wounded person comes to you immediately after being wounded: and it is in winter days, then it is necessary that you should strive for the removal of the bone before the fourteenth day according to every condition.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is in the days of summer, then it is necessary that you remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the bone from the bandage becomes rotten, and those accidents which we have described happen.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	What if the fracture of the bone has already reached the bandage touching the brain, and is with damage, and pulling: then it is necessary that you cut the damaged and pulled part, according to what I will tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is that you shave the head of the wounded, and uncover the bone as much as is possible for you, and according to the shape of the wound, and what is least above the weak part.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	What if there occurs to you during the uncovering of the bone a flow of blood, or a hot abscess: then apply to it what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And it is that you fill the place with cloths soaked in wine and rose oil: and make the wound rest, until the abscess settles, and you are secure from the flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin with the cure of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And that is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	One method indeed is, that you cut the bone with a strict razor-shaped incisor: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then administer another incisor wider than the first one, but only for a short time: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then administer also another incisor even wider also than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second method is, that you have a number of different incisors: some of which are wider than others, and some of them shorter than others: and let them be sharpened at the ends, and let them be made from hardened iron or steel: and use facility in striking on the incisor, so that it does not strike the head, and harm it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If the bone is strong and hard, then it is necessary that you perforate around it before you apply the incision instrument, with non-penetrating awls which are called non-penetrating awls; and they are not called thus, except that they themselves do not penetrate beyond the limit of the bony tissue to what is behind it: because the awl has a round extremity above what is under its pointed head, similar to a margin, and a small circle prevents submersion and penetration of the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it is suitable for you to take a large number of these awls, each one of which suits the thickness of the bone, until there is an awl available to you for every skull: whose pointed extremity's quantity in length and width is, according to the quantity of the thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three species of awls, or trephines.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The quality of perforating around a fractured bone is: that you place the awl on the bone and turn it with your fingers until you know that the bone has already been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then exchange the awl to another place, and put what is between every hole a quantity of thickness of the radius, or around it.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with incision instruments what is between every hole in the bone: and make it thinner than you can above that from the fineness of lightness, as we have said, until you eradicate the bone, either with your hand, or with some other one of the instruments which you have prepared for it: such as pincers and subtle borers.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary that you proceed with all caution, lest the awl or incision instrument touch anything of the brain.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When you have perforated around the bone and it has been separated from the brain, if it was continuous with it, and you extract it, it is necessary that you scrape and smooth out the extremity of what remains in the bone with another instrument similar to an incision instrument.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	The needle should be thin and finer than those of other surgeons.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	What remains from the small bones and sawdust, then take it with ease, along with what you have among your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then treat the wound afterwards with bandages and ointments which we mentioned.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another method of the operation is easy, far from fear, which Galen said and praised it with great praise, and this is his statement.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you first to begin to remove the piece of bone from the place where the fracture is most violent and most apparent, until when you have removed that piece and placed under it the extremity of this grooved incisor, of which this is the shape.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the grooved part does not cut gently, and its pointed part on both sides of it proceeds along the length, as you see, so that the grooved part is attached to the saw, with its pointed face cutting into the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike the incisor on one side with a small hammer, until you cut the whole bone with ease, as it turns out, and you will be safe from the accident that you fear, namely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the doctor were not more stupid than men and more ignorant of it, nor asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the bandage in certain places, he would cut it away from it with the extremity of the grooved incisor itself, and free it from it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	For it is freed from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not penetrate to the bandage, and what is cut away from the bone is its surface, and remaining in it are roughness and subtle sawdust, then it is necessary that you scrape away that roughness and remove those sawdust with fine rasps which you have prepared in a number of different quantities, so that it is possible for you to apply them in every place more conveniently and more correctly, according to what the operation leads you to, and the bone itself, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary that you manage with a rasp, which in the first place has a wider tooth than those of other rasps.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use afterwards something more subtle than it.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not cease to make that a second time in succession until you reach making something thinner and more subtle than all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	In each and every one of the remaining small fissures or tiny little fractures, it is necessary that you administer care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And it is a thing which is not hidden from everyone, that in this art there is something to be studied, and it stands upon what we have written, and we show in great fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	If indeed a piece of cloth is detected and retained when you extract the bone: then it is necessary that you take a linen cloth, according to the quantity of the wound, and soak it in rose oil, and put it on the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another cloth doubled or tripled, and soak it in wine and rose oil, and put it on the first cloth: and do that as easily as you can over it, so that it does not press on the spleen.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then administer over it a wide bandage: and do not bind it, except in the amount that will hold the wound so much: and leave it with this care for one day, or two days, until you are secure from a hot abscess.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then undo it, and administer after that medicines with which there is a dry excess, such as the roots of lily, and flour of herbs, and powder of frankincense, and aristolochia, and similar to them: and it is that you make from these medicines a powder, which will be powdered over the wounds as they are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally administer on it every medicine of a property which is that it cleanses and does not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And beware according to your virtue, that the wound is in your cure clear: nor is there in it filth of ointment, nor foulness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	And do not allow the pus to gather in it at all: for when pus gathers on the membrane of the brain, it corrupts it, and putrefies it, and a great evil happens to the weak after that; and now it happens in the cerebral membranes, when the mouth is cleansed from it, especially when the care of it is neglected, blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Consider then, that if there happen to the weak the accidents which we have said, you should know, that it is pernicious without a doubt.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if the blackness does not happen, except from the medicine which is put on it, and it is in the virtue of that medicine, that it makes that blackness: then you should take one part of honey, three parts of rose oil, and anoint the cloth with them.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then put it on the cerebral membrane: afterwards cure it with the species of cure which are suitable, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	On the restoration of the nose when it is fractured.
Caput IIII.	Chapter 4.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that the nose is not fractured except when its two upper parts break at the same time, or one of them: because it itself has two bones: for the lower part of it is cartilaginous, does not fracture, and nothing happens to it except bruising, and twisting, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of its two parts is fractured, then you should insert a small finger into the nostril, and straighten that fracture with your index finger and thumb, until the nose returns to its natural figure: and this should be done with skill.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware, that pain does not happen to the weak because of your operation.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	What if the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and does not reach to that finger then it is necessary that it be adjusted by a small thickness of the radius.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If the fracture is in two parts, then make it similar to that and restore it immediately on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day with rest of a warm apostume.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then insert into the extremity of the nose a linen pledget from a linen cloth, if the fracture is in one part: or insert two pledgets if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be in the pledget a thickness of such quantity that it fills the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the ancient restorers have said that the pledgets should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	That however does not seem to me, but rather it is necessary that the pledget be soaked in the white of an egg mixed with powder of meal.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then leave the pledget until the bone becomes firm and the cartilage becomes hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a feather of a goose is inserted into the nose in place of a pledget, after which a soft cloth is wrapped over it: and it is done so that it holds the fracture of the nose more vigorously, and so that it does not prevent the weak from inhaling.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this is not a necessary thing.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you want, do that: and if you want, do pledgets.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.
